result.markdown:
---
title: "R and SQLite"
author: "Randi Bolt"
date: "2023-01-23"
categories: [R, SQL]
toc: true
draft: false
---


In this post I use fake hospital data to answer questions using both R and SQL (Structured Query Language) via a R package called RSQLite. 

![](../../00_img/SQL-and-R.png)


# `0.` Introduction 

There are a handful of programming languages that data scientists use when querying, analyzing, and manipulating data. What I have found in my experience, research, and interviews with various companies is that while R and Python have a lot more power in what they are capable of producing, SQL is a fairly common way most people (especially outside of data science) query their data. So to get more practice using SQL (and R) I pulled some data and 10 questions off a website called [Learn SQL](https://www.sql-practice.com/), and will be answering them in both R and SQL. 

## `0.1` Packages

For all my data quering and manipulation in R I will be using the [tidyverse](https://www.tidyverse.org/).


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```
:::


To run create a SQL database, and run SQL queries in R chunks I will be using a package called [RSQLite](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/RSQLite/index.html). 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(RSQLite)
```
:::


## `0.2` Data 

This post will use two data sets that I copied from [Learn SQL](https://www.sql-practice.com/): 

1. `patients`: Which includes patient_id, first_name, last_name, gender, birth_date, city, province_id, allergies, height, and weight. Note I only copied the first 1000 entries. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
patients <- utils::read.csv('../../00_data/patients.csv')
```
:::



2. `province_names`: Which includes province_id, and province_name. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
province_names <- utils::read.csv("../../00_data/province_names.csv")
```
:::


## `0.3` Database 

To start I am using the `dbConnect()`, and `SQLite()` functions to create a hospital 

Since SQL lets the user access and manipulate data from a [database](https://www.oracle.com/database/what-is-database/), it is important to create this data base. 

Create a `Hospital` database to store the `patients` data. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
hosp <- RSQLite::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(),
                           "../../00_data/Hospital.db")
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbWriteTable(hosp,
                      "patients",
                      patients)
RSQLite::dbWriteTable(hosp,
                      "province_names",
                      province_names)
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbListTables(hosp)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "patients"       "province_names"
```
:::
:::


# `1.` Show the first ten rows of `patients` data.

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
utils::head(patients, 10)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
   patient_id first_name  last_name gender birth_date            city
1           1     Donald Waterfield      M 1963-02-12          Barrie
2           2     Mickey     Baasha      M 1981-05-28          Dundas
3           3       Jiji     Sharma      M 1957-09-05        Hamilton
4           4      Blair       Diaz      M 1967-01-07        Hamilton
5           5    Charles      Wolfe      M 2017-11-19         Orillia
6           6        Sue     Falcon      F 2017-09-30            Ajax
7           7     Thomas     ONeill      M 1993-01-31      Burlington
8           8      Sonny    Beckett      M 1952-12-11 Port Hawkesbury
9           9     Sister    Spitzer      F 1966-10-15         Toronto
10         10     Cedric   Coltrane      M 1961-11-10         Toronto
   province_id  allergies height weight
1           ON       NULL    156     65
2           ON      Sulfa    185     76
3           ON Penicillin    194    106
4           ON       NULL    191    104
5           ON Penicillin     47     10
6           ON Penicillin     43      5

8           NS       NULL    174    105

10          ON       NULL    157     61
```

:::


## SQL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp, 
                    "SELECT * 
                     FROM patients 
                     LIMIT 10"
                    )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
   patient_id first_name  last_name gender birth_date            city
1           1     Donald Waterfield      M 1963-02-12          Barrie
2           2     Mickey     Baasha      M 1981-05-28          Dundas
3           3       Jiji     Sharma      M 1957-09-05        Hamilton
4           4      Blair       Diaz      M 1967-01-07        Hamilton
5           5    Charles      Wolfe      M 2017-11-19         Orillia
6           6        Sue     Falcon      F 2017-09-30            Ajax
7           7     Thomas     ONeill      M 1993-01-31      Burlington
8           8      Sonny    Beckett      M 1952-12-11 Port Hawkesbury
9           9     Sister    Spitzer      F 1966-10-15         Toronto
10         10     Cedric   Coltrane      M 1961-11-10         Toronto
   province_id  allergies height weight
1           ON       NULL    156     65
2           ON      Sulfa    185     76
3           ON Penicillin    194    106
4           ON       NULL    191    104
5           ON Penicillin     47     10
6           ON Penicillin     43      5
7           ON       NULL    180    117

9           ON Penicillin    173     95
10          ON       NULL    157     61
```
:::
:::


# `2.` Show total patients admitted.

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
base::data.frame("total_admissions" = base::nrow(patients))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  total_admissions
1             1000
```
:::
:::


## SQL
	

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT COUNT(*) AS total_admissions 
                     FROM patients"
                    )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  total_admissions
1             1000
```
:::
:::


# `3.` Show first and last name as full_name.

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
utils::head(
  base::data.frame(
    full_name = base::paste0(patients$first_name, 
                             " ", 
                             patients$last_name)), 
  10)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
           full_name
1  Donald Waterfield
2      Mickey Baasha
3        Jiji Sharma
4         Blair Diaz
5      Charles Wolfe
6         Sue Falcon
7      Thomas ONeill
8      Sonny Beckett
9     Sister Spitzer
10   Cedric Coltrane
```
:::
:::


## SQL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
  "SELECT first_name || ' ' || last_name AS full_name 
   FROM patients 
   LIMIT 10"
   )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
           full_name
1  Donald Waterfield
2      Mickey Baasha
3        Jiji Sharma
4         Blair Diaz
5      Charles Wolfe
6         Sue Falcon
7      Thomas ONeill
8      Sonny Beckett
9     Sister Spitzer
10   Cedric Coltrane
```
:::
:::


# `4` Show unique cities that are in province_id 'NS'?

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
patients %>% 
  filter(province_id == "NS") %>%
  summarise(unique_cities = unique(city)) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
    unique_cities
1 Port Hawkesbury
2         Halifax
```
:::
:::



## SQL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dbGetQuery(hosp,
           "SELECT DISTINCT(city) AS unique_cities 
            FROM patients 
            WHERE province_id IS 'NS'"
           )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
    unique_cities
1 Port Hawkesbury
2         Halifax
```
:::
:::

    
# `5.` Show the total amount of male patients and the total amount of female patients.

Display the two results in the same row.

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
base::data.frame(
  male_count = base::length(base::which(patients$gender == 'M')),
  female_count = base::length(base::which(patients$gender == 'F'))
  )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  male_count female_count
1        543          457
```
:::
:::


## SQL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dbGetQuery(hosp,
           "SELECT 
           (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM patients WHERE gender = 'M') AS male_count, 
           (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM patients WHERE gender = 'F') AS female_count")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  male_count female_count
1        543          457
```
:::
:::


# `6.` Show all allergies ordered by popularity. Remove NULL values from query.

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
patients %>% 
  filter(allergies != "NULL") %>%
  group_by(allergies) %>%
  summarise(total_diagnosis = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(total_diagnosis)) %>%
  head(10)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 10 × 2
   allergies   total_diagnosis
   <chr>                 <int>
 1 Penicillin              230
 2 Codeine                  58
 3 Sulfa                    35
 4 ASA                      16
 5 Sulfa Drugs              13
 6 Tylenol                  11
 7 Wheat                    11
 8 Peanuts                  10
 9 Bee Stings                9
10 Iodine                    9
```
:::
:::


## SQL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dbGetQuery(hosp,
           "SELECT allergies,
            COUNT(*) AS total_diagnosis
            FROM patients
            WHERE allergies IS NOT 'NULL'
            GROUP BY allergies
            ORDER BY total_diagnosis DESC
            LIMIT 10"
           )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     allergies total_diagnosis
1   Penicillin             230
2      Codeine              58
3        Sulfa              35
4          ASA              16
5  Sulfa Drugs              13
6        Wheat              11
7      Tylenol              11
8      Peanuts              10
9       Iodine               9
10  Bee Stings               9
```
:::
:::


# `7.` Display the total amount of patients for each province. Order by descending.

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
base::merge(province_names, patients, by = "province_id") %>%
  group_by(province_name) %>%
  summarise(patient_count = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(patient_count))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 8 × 2
  province_name             patient_count
  <chr>                             <int>
1 Ontario                             954
2 Alberta                              14
3 British Columbia                     11
4 Nova Scotia                           9
5 Manitoba                              7
6 Newfoundland and Labrador             2
7 Quebec                                2
8 Saskatchewan                          1
```
:::
:::


## SQL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT province_name,
                     COUNT(*) as patient_count
                     FROM patients pa
                     join province_names pr on pr.province_id = pa.province_id
                     group by pr.province_id
                     order by patient_count desc")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
              province_name patient_count
1                   Ontario           954
2                   Alberta            14
3          British Columbia            11
4               Nova Scotia             9
5                  Manitoba             7
6                    Quebec             2
7 Newfoundland and Labrador             2
8              Saskatchewan             1
```
:::
:::


# `8.` Show the provinces that has more patients identified as 'M' than 'F'. Must only show full province_name. 

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
base::merge(province_names, patients, by = "province_id") %>%
  dplyr::group_by(province_name) %>%
  dplyr::count(gender == "M", gender == "F") %>%
  dplyr::slice(base::which.max(n)) %>%
  dplyr::summarise(province_name = province_name)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 8 × 1
  province_name            
  <chr>                    
1 Alberta                  
2 British Columbia         
3 Manitoba                 
4 Newfoundland and Labrador
5 Nova Scotia              
6 Ontario                  
7 Quebec                   
8 Saskatchewan             
```
:::
:::


## SQL 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT pr.province_name
                     FROM patients AS pa
                     JOIN province_names AS pr ON pa.province_id = pr.province_id
                     GROUP BY pr.province_id
                     HAVING
                     COUNT( CASE WHEN gender = 'M' THEN 1 END) >
                     COUNT( CASE WHEN gender = 'F' THEN 1 END)")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
              province_name
1                   Alberta
2          British Columbia
3                  Manitoba
4 Newfoundland and Labrador
5               Nova Scotia
6                   Ontario
7                    Quebec
8              Saskatchewan
```
:::
:::


# `9.` Each admission costs $50 for patients without insurance, and $10 for patients with insurance. All patients with an even patient_id have insurance.

Give each patient a 'Yes' if they have insurance, and a 'No' if they don't have insurance. Add up the admission_total cost for each has_insurance group.

## R


::: {.cell}

:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
for(i in 1:length(patients$patient_id))
  {
  if(patients$patient_id[[i]]%%2==1){
     patients$has_insurance[[i]] <- "Yes"
  }else{
    patients$has_insurance[[i]] <- "No"
  }
}

#. patients
```
:::


## SQL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT 
                        CASE WHEN patient_id % 2 = 0 Then 'Yes'
                        ELSE 'No' 
                        END as has_insurance,
                     SUM(
                        CASE WHEN patient_id % 2 = 0 Then 10
                        ELSE 50 
                        END
                         ) as cost_after_insurance
                     FROM patients 
                     GROUP BY has_insurance;")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  has_insurance cost_after_insurance
1            No                25000
2           Yes                 5000
```
:::
:::


# `10.` We are looking for a specific patient. Pull all columns for the patient who matches the following criteria:

- First_name contains an 'b' after the first two letters.
- Identifies their gender as 'F'
- Their weight would be between 50kg and 70kg
- Their patient_id is an odd number
- They are from the city 'Burlington'

## R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
patients %>%
  filter(base::grepl("^.{2}[b]", first_name),
         gender == "F",
         weight > 50 && weight < 80,
         patient_id %%2==1,
         city == "Burlington")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  patient_id first_name last_name gender birth_date       city province_id
1        695    Sabrina    Hettie      F 2000-11-25 Burlington          ON
   allergies height weight has_insurance
1 Penicillin    160     51           Yes
```
:::
:::


## SQL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT *
                     FROM patients
                     WHERE
                      first_name LIKE '__b%'
                      AND gender = 'F'
                      AND weight BETWEEN 50 AND 70
                      AND patient_id % 2 = 1
                      AND city = 'Burlington';")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  patient_id first_name last_name gender birth_date       city province_id
1        695    Sabrina    Hettie      F 2000-11-25 Burlington          ON
   allergies height weight
1 Penicillin    160     51
```
:::
:::
